Controversies over Sin and Grace Are Addressed
Period: !!smallcaps|ad!! 250–431
Description: The early church debated the nature of sin and grace and its relation to baptized members of the church.
Summary: Schisms and controversies arose within the early church after periods of persecution.
The Roman Empire had required Christians to offer pagan sacrifices, hand over sacred texts to be burned, and other acts that were against the Christian faith.
After persecution subsided, the early church began to debate how lapsed Christians were to be treated.

While some church leaders advocated for the readmission of those who repented and completed penance, others insisted that the church was a place for saints---namely, those who had not fallen back into sin after conversion.
Further debates over the nature of sin, grace, human will, and forgiveness arose as the church continued to develop its theology and doctrine.
Schisms and controversies that were deemed unorthodox were condemned as the church further defined its doctrine of soteriology and the nature of the church.
Key Developments
A system of penance was established for readmitting Christians who had lapsed during persecution or were guilty of immorality (200s).
The early church debated the nature of the church and its relation to salvation and the forgiveness of sins (200s–300s).
The early church debated the nature of baptism and the Eucharist (200s-300s).
Schisms developed as the church debated the readmission of lapsed Christians who had been baptized (200s-300s).
Pelagius developed a soteriology which affirmed the innate goodness of humanity which is capable of achieving salvation based on the example of Jesus (400s).
Augustine of Hippo defended orthodoxy against Donatism and Pelagianism (400s).
The Western church affirmed the theology of Augustine (431).
Key People
Bishops

Pope Calixtus I (d. 222): bishop of Rome (c. 217–222) and martyr; he took a generous approach to readmitting Christians who were guilty of immorality, which led to criticism from other church leaders.

Cyprian of Carthage (201–258): North African bishop of Carthage; Latin church father; he left Carthage during the Decian persecution, and, upon his return, was involved with the debate on readmitting lapsed Christians; author of On the Unity of the Church and On the Lapsed, which were written during the Novatian Controversy.
Caecilian of Carthage (d. 340): bishop of Carthage; his appointment as bishop led to the Donatist Controversy; attended the First Council of Nicaea.

Augustine of Hippo (November 13, 354–August 28, 430): North African bishop of Hippo, monk, and theologian; Latin church father; developed Augustinianism; opponent of the Donatists and Pelagius; author of On Baptism, Against the Donatists, which addresses the sacrament of baptism and refutes the arguments of the Donatists, and On Nature and Grace, written in response to Pelagius' On Nature against Pelagianism.
Schism Leaders
Novatian of Rome (200–258): presbyter at Rome and theologian; his followers were known as Novatianists who refused full readmission to the church to lapsed Christians.
Donatus (fourth century): bishop of Carthage; inspired Donatist sect, which argued clergy who committed sin could not administer valid sacraments.
Pelagius (c. 390–418): British monk and theologian; known for Pelagianism; opponent of Augustine of Hippo; author of On Nature.
Epistles
Letter to Catholics on the Sect of the Donatist (Augustine of Hippo, c. 401): addressed to catholic bishops; addresses the theological issues of Donatism.

On the Lapsed (Cyprian of Carthage, 251): written during the Novatian Controversy; addresses Christians who lapsed during the Decian persecution and advocates for penance before readmission into the church.

Key Events
200s: Novatian Controversy emerges in the early church over lapsed Christians.
250: Christians are persecuted under Decius.
251: The Council of Carthage rules to allow readmission of lapsed Christians after penance.
303–311: Christians are persecuted under Diocletian.
312: Donatist Controversy emerges in the early church.
314: The Council of Arles condemns Donatism.
386: Augustine converts to Christianity.
early 400s: Donatist schism emerges over clergy, sin, and the sacraments.
431: The First Council of Ephesus condemns Pelagianism.
Key Places
Carthage was the bishopric of Cyprian, Caecilian, and Donatus; an ecclesial center for African Christianity; Donatism originated here.
Hippo was the bishopric of Augustine.
North Africa experienced persecution under Decius; was the center of early church controversies over the readmission of lapsed Christians.
Roman Empire was the location of the persecution of Christians in the early church.
Rome was the ecclesial center of the Western church; capital of the Roman Empire; Novatianism originated here.
Key Concepts
Augustinianism developed during the Pelagian controversy.
Donatism developed in North Africa after the Diocletian persecution.
Ecclesiology developed as the church debated the readmission of lapsed Christians and its authority to forgive sin.
Novatianism developed in Rome after the Decian persecution.
Pelagianism was condemned by the Catholic Church; asserted the human will was free from the effects of original sin.
Penance developed into a sacrament of the church.
Persecution led to some Christians, called lapsi, denying the faith.
The church debated the validity of sacraments administered by bishops who had lapsed or were guilty of immorality.
